item.title: Hash trails
item.description:
Several Hash House Harrier groups run all over London each week. Each week the location of the trails varies as that week’s “hare” lays the trail in an area they know well. I have been collecting the GPS routes of the trails from Strava for each group and plotting them on a map using Python.

If you are interested in running/drinking with one of the Hashes, check our when and where upcoming hash trails will be on the London Hash House Harriers site or the London Hashing Site (LaSH).

Most recent trails

The map below shows the trails run over the last week (or so) by the various Hash House Harrier groups around London. You can zoom in on the map, and click on the location icon to get details of which group each trail belongs to.

Full page version of map

Previous Trails

Below are links to maps showing the trails run in previous weeks/months.

item.title: Strava (GPS) art
item.description:
Strava art (or GPS art) is running/cycling a route with the aim of creating a picture with the GPS recording of your activity.

Below is a collection of trails I have run to create some Strava art. The GPS route of my run was recorded on my Garmin running watch and then plotted on the map once complete.

Table of Contents

  • Cats
  • Easter bunny
  • Kiwi

Cats

Two varieties on the cat theme run. Both are a little over 10km.

Easter bunny

For Easter I ran 18km in the shape of a rabbit. Some of the narrow London streets flanked by tall buildings make for some wobbly GPS readings, and there was one part where I had to scramble over some construction work to stay on track. But overall I was fairly happy with it as a first attempt.

Kiwi

For ANZAC day: 21.5 km loop taking in the City, Regents Canal, and some of the parks in London.

Along the route I did come across two locked gates which impeded my progress. But I was able to navigate around them without affecting the overall route too much.
